newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish bonds up, yield gap less in pre-holiday lull.
newsitem.headline: Danish bonds up, yield gap less in pre-holiday lull.

text.p: Danish bond prices rose slightly, the 10-year yield gap with Germany narrowed marginally and dealers expected little to happen on Wednesday in a quiet market prior to Thursday's Ascension Day holiday.

"There's nothing much to report today. It is going to be calm up to the close with Wall Street's opening possibly sparking a little activity. Tomorrow's holiday in much of Europe is putting a damper on trade," one dealer said.
The benchmark eight percent state bond due 2006 was up 0.09 point from the opening at 110.44, yielding 6.41 percent in turnover of only 720 million crowns.
The 2006 benchmark's June future rose 0.17 point to 110.05 with 130 contracts traded. The six percent mortgage bond due 2026 gained 0.33 point to 88.55.
The crown traded at 3.8078 per mark at 1130 gmt, up a smidgen from around 3.8085 at the opening.
The 10-year yield gap with Germany narrowed one basis point to 65.
The Central Bank was active on the market selling a total of 355 million crowns worth of five percent 2005 and seven percent 2007 and 2024 bonds as part of its routine financing operations.
